awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Ultrasound-Activated Shape Memory Lengthening Device for Orthopedic Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a medical device for the treatment of bone fractures and deformities in pediatric patients with immature skeletons.  Fifteen to thirty percent of all fractures in the pediatric population occur close to the physeal or growth plate. These pediatric patients have reported complications such as the occurrence of uneven bone growth and the need for follow-up surgeries to readjust devices as bones mature. The proposed technology is a growth-friendly surgical treatment that allows bone union and subsequent lengthening during child growth. The proposed technology is designed to provide adequate forces for the initial stabilization of deformed bone parts, as well as adaptable forces that are required to accommodate the natural tendency for bones to lengthen. The proposed technology may be extended to fracture fixation in osteoporotic and osteopenic bones where there are significant changes in the porosity, density, and strength of bones over time. Applications of the proposed technology may decrease recovery time and reduce health care costs for the treatment of bone deformities.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an ultrasound-activated shape memory lengthening device for the treatment of bone fractures and deformities in pediatric patients with immature skeletons.  The proposed technology uses ultrasound heating to activate a shape change in the biocompatible material, nitinol, in a non-invasive orthopedic surgical device. Initial results with the proposed technology have demonstrated that each increase in temperature from ultrasound causes a slight change in the shape of a nitinol device, which may allow a bone to naturally lengthen without force (for growth plate fractures) or force the bones to lengthen (for scoliosis treatments) after the initial stages of the surgery. The ultrasound heating is on the order of a few degrees – well within the range for activating the shape change and still be accommodated by the tissues adjacent to the implant in the body. The temperature-associated shape change and lengthening may be tailored to suit different bone morphologies or patient requirements.  In addition, the proposed device may minimize or eliminate surgeries for readjustment and may reduce complications by 15-50%.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Overview: This project focused on conducting customer-discovery interviews to validate the intended use of a nitinol shape memory biomedical device as well as improve its commercial development. The current fixation plates and rods used for open reduction surgeries for growth plate fractures have reported implant complications, including the need for follow-up surgeries to adjust these devices as bones mature. It is essential to provide alternative growth-friendly surgical treatments that may reduce or eliminate post-surgery readjustments. The thermoelastic transformation from martensite to austenite in nitinol allows a previously deformed material to return to its original shape after heating in multiple steps. Each increase in temperature can result in the plate/rod changing its shape slightly, thus, can be designed in a manner that the shape change can either force the bone to lengthen or allow the bone to naturally lengthen without force. It is anticipated that ultrasound heat can be used to activate shape change in nitinol to allow gradual extension of the plate to permit bone remodeling.  

Customer Discovery Process: More than 120 professionals in the fields of medicine, biomedical device development, manufacturing, and key hospital managers were interviewed over the project duration. This process helped us to (a) practically understand the different stages involved in device development, and (b) discover that amongst the key elements of the value proposition,  our customers (the surgeons) valued the convenience of the device, i.e., how much it makes the surgical procedure less time-consuming and not cumbersome.  

Research Impact/Outcomes: This project gave a holistic view of translating technology from the research lab to the market. The self-adjusting nature of the proposed device will open doors to manufacturing patient-specific orthopedic devices that can correct bone deformities in multiple locations throughout the body, including scoliosis of the spine. An important outcome of this project was the awareness of the increasing demand for patient-specific biomedical devices, where additive manufacturing may be the most viable option for device fabrication. Moreover, this I-Corps research project strengthened the partnership between our research team (academia), orthopedic surgeons, device vendors, and manufacturers. This was in alignment with the Cleveland Innovation District's objective to bring world-class healthcare to the people within Northeast Ohio. The project offered hands-on learning and research experience for a female (minority) student who has started her Ph.D. in biomedical engineering. The customer discovery process exposed her to materials engineering, computer simulation, and most importantly entrepreneurship. This early research experience provided the mentoring needed for her to succeed in her education. 

 


Last Modified: 08/04/2022
Modified by: Josiah S Owusu-Danquah
